TopicTitle: How much fuel does it take to lift off of mun

Articles.Content:
I would like to know how much fuel it takes for me to get off of mun. please help. The engines im using are four nuclear engines with 1800 units of fuel.

Edited June 19, 2013 by Tangyboxhead

In the setting menu, reduce the max debris to 0. Reload you game. Debris will still be there. Quit you game and reload again. This should works.

Normally, you may be able to Abort flight in the tracking station without "fly" the thing.

can also abort the flights from the tracking station.

aannnd I cant read it seems

Edited June 19, 2013 by Procyon
already stated

In the setting menu, reduce the max debris to 0. Reload you game. Debris will still be there. Quit you game and reload again. This should works.

Normally, you may be able to Abort flight in the tracking station without "fly" the thing.

Okay it worked. Thanks. This will solve my launch-pad lag.

In the setting menu, reduce the max debris to 0. Reload you game. Debris will still be there. Quit you game and reload again. This should works.

Normally, you may be able to Abort flight in the tracking station without "fly" the thing.

I needed this aswell, thanks.

I would like to know how much fuel it takes for me to get off of mun. please help. The engines im using are four nuclear engines with 1800 units of fuel.

Depends on the overall mass of your ship. Save it, try for orbit, check fuel gauge and you'll have your answer.

Did you edit away your original question or something?

FYI. If you have a new question, please start a new topic. Don't change the title and content of your OP; it makes for confusing threads.

I would like to know how much fuel it takes for me to get off of mun. please help. The engines im using are four nuclear engines with 1800 units of fuel.

It takes about 580 m/s to reach a 10km orbit from the surface and about 670 m/s to reach 100km.
MechJeb or KerbalEngineer both have delta-v functions in the VAB so you can see how much oomph your rocket has. How much fuel is very dependent on the mass of your lander.
